The Bearhug Squat-to-Stand is a full-body exercise working major lower-body muscles (glutes, quads, hamstrings) and postural muscles (core, back, shoulders, biceps) to improve functional strength and technique, emphasizing an upright torso by holding a weight (like a sandbag) close to the chest, challenging stabilization and promoting better mobility. The movement pattern involves hinging at the hips and squatting down while maintaining tension to keep the weight stable, then driving up powerfully. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers: Glutes, Quadriceps, Hamstrings (for the squat). 
• Core & Posture: Abdominals, Obliques, Lower Back (erector spinae), Upper Back (traps, rhomboids). 
• Upper Body (Stabilizers/Grip): Biceps, Forearms, Shoulders (deltoids), Lats (for holding the weight). [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Setup: Stand over the weight (sandbag/ball), hinge at the hips, and scoop your hands underneath to hug it to your chest. 
2. Descent: Initiate the squat by pushing hips back, keeping your chest up and core braced, as if tearing a newspaper with your feet (external rotation) to engage glutes and maintain tension. 
3. Bottom: Reach the deepest comfortable depth with an upright torso, ensuring your back maintains its natural curve. 
4. Ascent: Drive through your feet, extending hips and knees powerfully to return to standing, keeping the weight pressed firmly to your chest. [4, 6, 11, 12]  

Key Benefits 

• Improves Posture: Forces an upright torso, strengthening postural muscles. 
• Builds Functional Strength: Mimics real-world lifting and carrying. 
• Enhances Core Stability: Unstable weight (like a sandbag) constantly challenges core stabilizers. 
• Develops Grip: Holding the object firmly builds grip strength. [2, 3, 4, 5, 8]
